panels.description: Number of active controllers in the cluster.
panels.title: Active Controllers

panels.description: Number of Brokers Online
panels.title: Brokers Online

panels.description: Partitions that are online
panels.title: Online Partitions

panels.description: Unclean leader election rate
panels.title: Unclean Leader Election Rate

panels.description: Number of under-replicated partitions (| ISR | < | all replicas |).
panels.title: Under Replicated Partitions

panels.description: Number of partitions under min insync replicas.
panels.title: Under Min ISR Partitions

panels.description: Number of partitions that dont have an active leader and are hence not writable or readable.
panels.title: Offline Partitions Count

panels.description:
Stray partitions in Kafka refer to partitions whose data directories remain on a broker, even though the broker no longer serves as a leader or a replica for those partitions.

Stray partitions could be left on a broker after reassignment or topic deletion.
panels.title: Stray Partitions Count

panels.description: indicate the number of partitions that have been incorrectly assigned to brokers or have been mishandled during a rebalance or assignment process
panels.title: Stray Partitions Miss Classified Count

panels.description: Number of leaders per broker. This should be mostly even across all brokers.
panels.title: Leader Count

panels.description:
Stray partitions in Kafka refer to partitions whose data directories remain on a broker, even though the broker no longer serves as a leader or a replica for those partitions.

Stray partitions could be left on a broker after reassignment or topic deletion.
panels.title: Stray Partitions Total Size

panels.description: Produce request rate.
panels.title: All Request Per Sec Across All Brokers

panels.description: All request rate, from all brokers - added together, with a 5 minutes avg
panels.title: Produce Request Per Sec

panels.description: Fetch request rate.
panels.title: Consumer Fetch Request Per Sec

panels.description: Fetch request rate.
panels.title: Broker Fetch Request Per Sec

panels.description: Offset Commit request rate.
panels.title: Offset Commit Request Per Sec

panels.description: Metadata request rate.
panels.title: Metadata request per sec

panels.description: The total number of bytes read by the broker process, including reads from all disks. The total doesnt include reads from page cache. Available only on Linux-based systems.
panels.title: Linux Disk Read Bytes

panels.description: The total number of bytes written by the broker process, including writes from all disks. Available only on Linux-based systems
panels.title: Linux Disk Write Bytes

panels.description: Size of the request queue. A congested request queue will not be able to process incoming or outgoing requests.
panels.title: Request Queue Size

panels.description: Size of the response queue. The response queue is unbounded. A congested response queue can result in delayed response times and memory pressure on the broker.
panels.title: Response Queue Size

panels.description: Average fraction of time the network processor threads are idle. Values are between 0 (all resources are used) and 100 (all resources are available)
panels.title: Network Processor Avg Usage Percent

panels.description: Average fraction of time the request handler threads are idle. Values are between 0 (all resources are used) and 100 (all resources are available).
panels.title: Request Handler Avg Percent

panels.description: : The number of in-sync replicas (ISRs) for a particular partition should remain fairly static, the only exceptions are when you are expanding your broker cluster or removing partitions. In order to maintain high availability, a healthy Kafka cluster requires a minimum number of ISRs for failover. A replica could be removed from the ISR pool for a couple of reasons: it is too far behind the leaders offset (user-configurable by setting the replica.lag.max.messages configuration parameter), or it has not contacted the leader for some time (configurable with the replica.socket.timeout.ms parameter). No matter the reason, an increase in IsrShrinksPerSec without a corresponding increase in IsrExpandsPerSec shortly thereafter is cause for concern and requires user intervention.The Kafka documentation provides a wealth of information on the user-configurable parameters for brokers.
panels.title: IsrShrinks per Sec

panels.description: : The number of in-sync replicas (ISRs) for a particular partition should remain fairly static, the only exceptions are when you are expanding your broker cluster or removing partitions. In order to maintain high availability, a healthy Kafka cluster requires a minimum number of ISRs for failover. A replica could be removed from the ISR pool for a couple of reasons: it is too far behind the leaders offset (user-configurable by setting the replica.lag.max.messages configuration parameter), or it has not contacted the leader for some time (configurable with the replica.socket.timeout.ms parameter). No matter the reason, an increase in IsrShrinksPerSec without a corresponding increase in IsrExpandsPerSec shortly thereafter is cause for concern and requires user intervention.The Kafka documentation provides a wealth of information on the user-configurable parameters for brokers.
panels.title: IsrExpands per Sec

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough IO threads or the CPU is a bottleneck, or the request queue isnt large enough. The request queue size should match the number of connections.
panels.title: Producer - RequestQueueTimeMs

panels.description: In most cases, a high value can imply slow local storage or the storage is a bottleneck. One should also investigate LogFlushRateAndTimeMs to know how long page flushes are taking, which will also indicate a slow disk. In the case of FetchFollower requests, time spent in LocalTimeMs can be the result of a ZooKeeper write to change the ISR.
panels.title: Producer - LocalTimeMs

panels.description: A high value can imply a slow network connection. For fetch request, if the remote time is high, it could be that there is not enough data to give in a fetch response. This can happen when the consumer or replica is caught up and there is no new incoming data. If this is the case, remote time will be close to the max wait time, which is normal. Max wait time is configured via replica.fetch.wait.max.ms and fetch.max.wait.ms.
panels.title: Producer - RemoteTimeMs

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough network threads or the network cant dequeue responses quickly enough, causing back pressure in the response queue.
panels.title: Producer - ResponseQueueTimeMs

panels.description: A high value can imply the zero-copy from disk to the network is slow, or the network is the bottleneck because the network cant dequeue responses of the TCP socket as quickly as theyre being created. If the network buffer gets full, Kafka will block.
panels.title: Producer - ResponseSendTimeMs

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough IO threads or the CPU is a bottleneck, or the request queue isnt large enough. The request queue size should match the number of connections.
panels.title: Consumer - RequestQueueTimeMs

panels.description: In most cases, a high value can imply slow local storage or the storage is a bottleneck. One should also investigate LogFlushRateAndTimeMs to know how long page flushes are taking, which will also indicate a slow disk. In the case of FetchFollower requests, time spent in LocalTimeMs can be the result of a ZooKeeper write to change the ISR.

panels.title: Consumer - ResponseSendTimeMs

panels.title: FetchFollower - RequestQueueTimeMs

In the case of FetchFollower requests, time spent in LocalTimeMs can be the result of a ZooKeeper write to change the ISR.

panels.description: This metric shows the total number of Fetch Session that are in the cache at the time.
panels.title: FetchSessionCache - Sessions in cache

panels.description: Eviction Rate per sec
panels.title: FetchSessionCache - Eviction Rate per sec

panels.description: Metadata request rate.
panels.title: Metadata request per sec

panels.description: Value of the replicas minimum fetch rate that measures the rate of fetching messages from the leader
panels.title: Replica - Min Fetch Rate

panels.description: Tracks the amount of time Acceptor is blocked from accepting connections. See KIP-402 for more details.
panels.title: Acceptor Blocked Percentage

panels.description: Number of consumer groups per group coordinator
panels.title: Consumer groups number per coordinator

panels.description: Number of consumer group per state
panels.title: Nb consumer groups per state

panels.description: The number of messages produced converted to match the log.message.format.version.
panels.title: Number of produced message conversion

panels.description: The number of messages consumed converted at consumer to match the log.message.format.version.
panels.title: Number of consumed message conversion

panels.description: Number of connection per client version
panels.title: Client version repartition

panels.description: Rate of bytes per second that is being uploaded by the archiver to cloud storage
panels.title: Upload bytes to cloud storage

panels.description: Number of times the archiver has reattempted to upload a non-active segment to cloud storage
panels.title: Retries per sec

panels.description: Number of bytes in non-active segments not yet uploaded by the archiver to cloud storage
panels.title: Total lag

panels.description: Number of partitions that the archiver was unable to upload that are in an error state
panels.title: Partitions in error

panels.description: Total tier size
panels.title: Storage distribution
